content: We've got massive economic issues, two wars, health care in disarray and on and on... So, what does the RNC decide is the most pressing issue? GOP, RNC to rebrand Democrats as 'Socialists' A member of the Republican National Committee told me Tuesday that when the RNC meets in an extraordinary special session next week, it will approve a resolution rebranding Democrats as the “Democrat Socialist Party.” When I asked if such a resolution would force RNC Chairman Michael Steele to use that label when talking about Democrats in all his speeches and press releases, the RNC member replied: “Who cares?” Which pretty much sums up the attitude some members of the RNC have toward their chairman these days. Steele wrote a memo last month opposing the resolution. Steele said that while he believes Democrats “are indeed marching America toward European-style socialism,” he also said in a (rare) flash of insight that officially referring to them as the Democrat Socialist Party “will accomplish little than to give the media and our opponents the opportunity to mischaracterize Republicans.” Read more: "http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0509/22445.html#ixzz0FXLnp9QH&B" Next they will be working on the "Nanny, nanny boo-boo" resolution... And they wonder why they are the incredibly shrinking party? This message has been edited. Last edited by: SeaWitch1220, Fri 15 May 2009 04:40 AM

Steele wrote a memo last month opposing the resolution. Steele said that while he believes Democrats “are indeed marching America toward European-style socialism,” he also said in a (rare) flash of insight that officially referring to them as the Democrat Socialist Party “will accomplish little than to give the media and our opponents the opportunity to mischaracterize Republicans.” Read more: "http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0509/22445.html#ixzz0FXLnp9QH&B" Next they will be working on the "Nanny, nanny boo-boo" resolution... And they wonder why they are the incredibly shrinking party? This message has been edited. Last edited by: SeaWitch1220, Fri 15 May 2009 04:40 AM

content: quote: Originally posted by 3678131: SeaWitch1220; quote: Just wait until the July 4th Tea Party events being planned right now, with the direct involvement of the RNC. The more Hammer and Sickle's we see displayed, along with Obama bashing compliments of the Neo-Right, should backfire on the RNC and the devout followers of Limbaugh/Coulter. I can't think of anything worse for the majority of level headed (middle of the road) Americans, than once again be subjected to such overt displays of animosity. And is Fox sponsoring the July tea bagger party?[/quote] Why is it people continue to assume the Republican Party or even Fox News sponsors these events???? Having watched the last tea party events on television, it was Fox news that gave them the most on air coverage. Plus, you had several GOP personalities speaking publicly at these events, in conjunction with Fox news. This gives the impression, that the RNC/GOP is orchestrating these events. You certainly don't see anyone from the Democratic party, in an alliance with the GOP publicly speaking at these events. So, whether or not the GOP is directly or indirectly involved in these events is irrelevant. What is relevent, are the speakers at these events, and their affiliation with the GOP. Those are the personalities the television/internet audience is viewing. And the viewing audience, won't forget who those people are. They are grassroots events organized by various people.. "http://www.teapartyday.com/" "http://www.reteaparty.com/" quote: The America’s Independence Day Tea Party Movement is a nationwide protest forum for any and all groups and individuals dissatisfied with the current governance of the United States, regardless of ideology, partisan identity, or political affiliation. [/QUOTE] That's fine. This organization may say they are bipartisan, and anyone with any political savvy would expect them to admit this. After all, they are trying to appeal to "all the people." However, when you have signs displaying President Obama as Adolf Hitler, and other signs and flags which are reminiscent of the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany at these events, the American audience is taking all of this in. What I'm trying to say, is that symbols have powerful meanings. And, I can't think of any symbol/s more overtly negative than the Hammer and Sickle, and the Swastika. Furthermore, I can't think of anything more offensive to the viewing American public, than those two particular symbols. Despite the large turn out at these events, it is the viewing public (whether on tv, newsprint or internet) that constitutes the larger majority. And, we have a saying in this country; "majority rules." No one starts a war--or rather, no one in his senses ought to do so--without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. Carl von Clausewitz
quote: Originally posted by 3678131: SeaWitch1220; quote: Just wait until the July 4th Tea Party events being planned right now, with the direct involvement of the RNC. The more Hammer and Sickle's we see displayed, along with Obama bashing compliments of the Neo-Right, should backfire on the RNC and the devout followers of Limbaugh/Coulter. I can't think of anything worse for the majority of level headed (middle of the road) Americans, than once again be subjected to such overt displays of animosity.
reply: And is Fox sponsoring the July tea bagger party?[/quote] Why is it people continue to assume the Republican Party or even Fox News sponsors these events???? Having watched the last tea party events on television, it was Fox news that gave them the most on air coverage. Plus, you had several GOP personalities speaking publicly at these events, in conjunction with Fox news. This gives the impression, that the RNC/GOP is orchestrating these events. You certainly don't see anyone from the Democratic party, in an alliance with the GOP publicly speaking at these events. So, whether or not the GOP is directly or indirectly involved in these events is irrelevant. What is relevent, are the speakers at these events, and their affiliation with the GOP. Those are the personalities the television/internet audience is viewing. And the viewing audience, won't forget who those people are. They are grassroots events organized by various people.. "http://www.teapartyday.com/" "http://www.reteaparty.com/" quote: The America’s Independence Day Tea Party Movement is a nationwide protest forum for any and all groups and individuals dissatisfied with the current governance of the United States, regardless of ideology, partisan identity, or political affiliation. [/QUOTE] That's fine. This organization may say they are bipartisan, and anyone with any political savvy would expect them to admit this. After all, they are trying to appeal to "all the people." However, when you have signs displaying President Obama as Adolf Hitler, and other signs and flags which are reminiscent of the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany at these events, the American audience is taking all of this in. What I'm trying to say, is that symbols have powerful meanings. And, I can't think of any symbol/s more overtly negative than the Hammer and Sickle, and the Swastika. Furthermore, I can't think of anything more offensive to the viewing American public, than those two particular symbols. Despite the large turn out at these events, it is the viewing public (whether on tv, newsprint or internet) that constitutes the larger majority. And, we have a saying in this country; "majority rules." No one starts a war--or rather, no one in his senses ought to do so--without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. Carl von Clausewitz
title: The RNC Working Hard For You!

content: We've got massive economic issues, two wars, health care in disarray and on and on... So, what does the RNC decide is the most pressing issue? GOP, RNC to rebrand Democrats as 'Socialists' A member of the Republican National Committee told me Tuesday that when the RNC meets in an extraordinary special session next week, it will approve a resolution rebranding Democrats as the “Democrat Socialist Party.” When I asked if such a resolution would force RNC Chairman Michael Steele to use that label when talking about Democrats in all his speeches and press releases, the RNC member replied: “Who cares?” Which pretty much sums up the attitude some members of the RNC have toward their chairman these days. Steele wrote a memo last month opposing the resolution. Steele said that while he believes Democrats “are indeed marching America toward European-style socialism,” he also said in a (rare) flash of insight that officially referring to them as the Democrat Socialist Party “will accomplish little than to give the media and our opponents the opportunity to mischaracterize Republicans.” Read more: "http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0509/22445.html#ixzz0FXLnp9QH&B" Next they will be working on the "Nanny, nanny boo-boo" resolution... And they wonder why they are the incredibly shrinking party? This message has been edited. Last edited by: SeaWitch1220, Fri 15 May 2009 04:40 AM

Steele wrote a memo last month opposing the resolution. Steele said that while he believes Democrats “are indeed marching America toward European-style socialism,” he also said in a (rare) flash of insight that officially referring to them as the Democrat Socialist Party “will accomplish little than to give the media and our opponents the opportunity to mischaracterize Republicans.” Read more: "http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0509/22445.html#ixzz0FXLnp9QH&B" Next they will be working on the "Nanny, nanny boo-boo" resolution... reply: I certainly agree with you on that point and probably several others. I cannot recall the last time I had any respect for the critters in office. It has been decades since there has been a glimmer of integrity in virtually any elected office or appointment. Yes, Im referring to both "Parties"...there is not a pennies' difference between them. Since the election though, its been enough to gag a maggot off a gut wagon... "Some people spend an entire lifetime wondering if they made a difference. The Marines dont have that problem." Pres. Reagan, 1985.
title: The RNC Working Hard For You!

title: The RNC Working Hard For You!

content: quote: Originally posted by 3678131: SeaWitch1220; quote: Just wait until the July 4th Tea Party events being planned right now, with the direct involvement of the RNC. The more Hammer and Sickle's we see displayed, along with Obama bashing compliments of the Neo-Right, should backfire on the RNC and the devout followers of Limbaugh/Coulter. I can't think of anything worse for the majority of level headed (middle of the road) Americans, than once again be subjected to such overt displays of animosity. And is Fox sponsoring the July tea bagger party?[/quote] Why is it people continue to assume the Republican Party or even Fox News sponsors these events???? Having watched the last tea party events on television, it was Fox news that gave them the most on air coverage. Plus, you had several GOP personalities speaking publicly at these events, in conjunction with Fox news. This gives the impression, that the RNC/GOP is orchestrating these events. You certainly don't see anyone from the Democratic party, in an alliance with the GOP publicly speaking at these events. So, whether or not the GOP is directly or indirectly involved in these events is irrelevant. What is relevent, are the speakers at these events, and their affiliation with the GOP. Those are the personalities the television/internet audience is viewing. And the viewing audience, won't forget who those people are. They are grassroots events organized by various people.. "http://www.teapartyday.com/" "http://www.reteaparty.com/" quote: The America’s Independence Day Tea Party Movement is a nationwide protest forum for any and all groups and individuals dissatisfied with the current governance of the United States, regardless of ideology, partisan identity, or political affiliation. [/QUOTE] That's fine. This organization may say they are bipartisan, and anyone with any political savvy would expect them to admit this. After all, they are trying to appeal to "all the people." However, when you have signs displaying President Obama as Adolf Hitler, and other signs and flags which are reminiscent of the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany at these events, the American audience is taking all of this in. What I'm trying to say, is that symbols have powerful meanings. And, I can't think of any symbol/s more overtly negative than the Hammer and Sickle, and the Swastika. Furthermore, I can't think of anything more offensive to the viewing American public, than those two particular symbols. Despite the large turn out at these events, it is the viewing public (whether on tv, newsprint or internet) that constitutes the larger majority. And, we have a saying in this country; "majority rules." No one starts a war--or rather, no one in his senses ought to do so--without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. Carl von Clausewitz

There is another saying...the squeaky wheel gets the grease, and the whine over the last few years has a leftsocialist lean. I must respectfully disagree with you Drmwvr. I am fully aware that many who are GOP, or Right Wing, listen to Fox news, and Fox only. Those who are Moderate to Liberal, lean more towards CNN, MSNBC, etc. This is just my opinion nothing more, but I personally enjoy watching CNN over all the rest. I believe they represent the news in the most factually "moderate" sense of reporting the news. Yes, I'm fully aware that CNN has been dubbed by the cons as the Commie News Network. But I disagree with that assessment.
